recommendations: Chaine Leaps is a series of jumps in which the skater alternates between the front and back legs.. For practicing Chaine Leaps as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Chaine turn combinations, Saute arabesque, Saute attitude for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Begin in B-plus position., Perform a chaine turn, swinging arms., Push off the back leg, leaping with straight legs., Land on the front leg, bending knees., Continue leaping with alternating legs. for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on coordination, additional exercises could include Pirouette with arms, Spotting practice, Quick footwork patterns.

Fish Roll and Flop is a movement where the dancer rolls their body in a fluid motion resembling the movement of a fish, while the Flop is a contemporary dance move where the dancer falls to the ground in a sudden and dramatic manner.. For practicing Fish Roll and Flop as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Cross-body shoulder stretch: Sit or stand with your feet hip-width apart. Reach one arm across your body, using your other arm to gently pull it towards your chest. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then switch sides., Thread the needle stretch: Begin on your hands and knees, then thread one arm through the space between your opposite arm and knee. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then switch sides., Reverse table-top pose: Sit on the ground with your hands behind you and your feet on the ground. Lift your hips up towards the ceiling, creating a table-top shape with your body. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then release. for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart and engage your core muscles for stability., Lift right shoulder up and back., Simultaneously lift left shoulder up and forward., Move right shoulder down and forward., Move left shoulder down and back, alternating continuously. for 3 repetitions for 5 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on coordination, additional exercises could include Pirouette with arms, Spotting practice, Quick footwork patterns.

Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plie variations: Try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions. , Releves variations: Single-leg, double-legs in first, second and fifth positions, releve passé, Arabesque balances, Spotting exercises: Doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, Flexibility stretching for 3 repetitions on each side for 5 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward. Evenly distribute the weight between your feet and core muscles for balance and control., Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot., Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control., As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn.            , Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. for 3 repetitions on each side for 5 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on coordination, additional exercises could include Pirouette with arms: Practice turning with different arm positions to improve your coordination. Start with simple arm positions and gradually increase the difficulty., Spotting practice: Improve your spotting technique by practicing half and full turns with a focus on spotting. Gradually increase the speed and difficulty of the turns., Quick footwork patterns: Improve your coordination and footwork by practicing quick combinations, such as chasses, sissonnes, and pas de bourrees..
